what: Variations of Parallel Coordinate Plots for Categorical Data
title: Variations of Parallel Coordinate Plots for Categorical Data
text: R package ggparallel implements combines different types parallel coordinate plots categorical data: hammock plots, parallel sets plots, common angle plots, well common angle plots hammock-like adjustment line widths.

title: Variations of Parallel Coordinate Plots for Categorical Data
text: package available CRAN: can install development version ggparallel GitHub :

title: Variations of Parallel Coordinate Plots for Categorical Data
code: library(ggparallel) #> Loading required package: ggplot2 data(mtcars)  ggparallel(list("gear", "cyl"), data=mtcars) ggparallel(list("gear", "cyl"), data=mtcars, method="hammock", ratio=0.25)

what: Data linking genes and pathways. — genes
title: Data linking genes and pathways. — genes
text: Table knownGene track UCSC Genes downloaded UCSC table browser human genome assembly (hg18, May 2006) filtered selection pathways associated human metabolism obtained KEGG PATHWAY database. Bioconductor package KEGG.db used provide mappings gene pathway identifiers.

title: Data linking genes and pathways. — genes

Data linking genes and pathways. — genes
text: Fujita PA, Rhead B, Zweig , Hinrichs , Karolchik D, Cline MS, Goldman M, Barber GP, Clawson H, Coelho , Diekhans M, Dreszer TR, Giardine BM, Harte RA, Hillman-Jackson J, Hsu F, Kirkup V, Kuhn RM, Learned K, Li CH, Meyer LR, Pohl , Raney BJ, Rosenbloom KR, Smith KE, Haussler D, Kent WJ. UCSC Genome Browser database: update 2011. Nucleic Acids Res. 2010 Oct 18. http://genome.ucsc.edu/index.html?org=Human&db=hg19&hgsid=289810087 Marc Carlson, Seth Falcon, Herve Pages Nianhua Li (). KEGG.db: set annotation maps KEGG. R package version 2.6.1. Kanehisa, M., Goto, S., Sato, Y., Furumichi, M., Tanabe, M.; KEGG integration interpretation large-scale molecular datasets. Nucleic Acids Res. 40, D109-D114 (2012) Kanehisa, M. Goto, S.; KEGG: Kyoto Encyclopedia Genes Genomes. Nucleic Acids Res. 28, 27-30 (2000).

title: Data linking genes and pathways. — genes
code: library(ggplot2) library(RColorBrewer) genes$chrom <- factor(genes$chrom, levels=c(paste("chr", 1:22, sep=""),   "chrX", "chrY")) ggparallel(   list("path", "chrom"),   text.offset = c(0.03, 0,-0.03),   data = genes,   width = 0.1,   order = c(1, 0),   angle = 0,   color = "white",   factorlevels =  c(sapply(unique(genes$chrom), as.character),unique(genes$path)) ) +  scale_fill_manual(    values = c(brewer.pal("YlOrRd", n = 9), rep("grey80", 24)),    guide = "none"  ) +  scale_colour_manual(    values = c(brewer.pal("YlOrRd", n = 9), rep("grey80", 24)),    guide = "none"  ) +  coord_flip()

what: Variations of parallel coordinate plots — ggparallel
title: Variations of parallel coordinate plots — ggparallel
text: ggparallel implements combines different types parallel coordinate plots categorical data: hammock plots,  parallel sets plots, common angle plots, common angle plots hammock-like adjustment line widths.

title: Variations of parallel coordinate plots — ggparallel
code: ggparallel(   vars = list(),   data,   weight = NULL,   method = "angle",   alpha = 0.5,   width = 0.25,   order = 1,   ratio = NULL,   asp = NULL,   label = TRUE,   label.colour = "grey90",   label.size = 4,   text.angle = 90,   text.offset = NULL,   same.level = FALSE,   ... )

title: Variations of parallel coordinate plots — ggparallel
text: vars list variable names included plotting. Order variables preserved display data data frame weight weighting variable - use character string method plotting method use - one angle, adj.angle, parset,  hammock, hammock plot aspect ratio needs fixed. alpha level alpha blending fill color ribbons, value 0 1, defaults 0.5. width width variables order flag variable three levels -1, 0, 1 levels decreasing order, levels increasing order levels unchanged. variable can either scalar vector ratio used methods angle adjustments (method = 'hammock', 'adj.angle'): specifies height (width horizontal displays) widest line ratio overall display height (width horizontal displays). asp aspect ratio plot - set default 1 case hammock plots. label binary variable (vector), whether labels shown. label.colour character colour label shown. Ignored, `label` FALSE. label.size numeric value determine size labels shown, defaults 4 text.angle numeric value determine angle labels shown. text.offset (vector) values offsetting labels .level variables using levels? yes, simplify labelling ... passed directly ggplot2 commands

title: Variations of parallel coordinate plots — ggparallel
text: returns  ggplot2 object can plotted directly used base  layer additional modifications.

title: Variations of parallel coordinate plots — ggparallel
text: Parallel sets suggested kosara:2006 visualization technique incorporate categorical variables parallel coordinate plot introduced wegman:1990 inselberg:1985. parallel sets implemented reduced representations neighboring two-dimensional relationships rather hierarchical version originally suggested. versions, however, show perceptual problems interpreting line widths, leading potentially wrong conclusions data. hammock display, introduced schonlau:2003, common angle plots two approaches fixing problem: Hammock plots linewidth adjusted factor countering strength illusion, common angle plot lines adjusted show angle - making line widths comparable across ribbons. Additionally, can also adjust ribbons common angle display angle, make appear width (height) across display. refer method adj.angle.

title: Variations of parallel coordinate plots — ggparallel
code: data(mtcars)  ggparallel(list("gear", "cyl"), data=mtcars)  ggparallel(list("gear", "cyl"), data=mtcars, method="hammock", ratio=0.25)   require(RColorBrewer) require(ggplot2) cols <- c(brewer.pal(4, "Reds")[-1], brewer.pal(4, "Blues")[-1]) ggparallel(list("gear", "cyl"), ratio=0.2, data=mtcars,            method="hammock", text.angle=0) +   scale_fill_manual(values=cols) + scale_colour_manual(values=cols) +   theme_bw()   ## combination of common angle plot and hammock adjustment: ggparallel(list("gear", "cyl"), data=mtcars, method="adj.angle",            ratio=2)   ## compare with method='parset' ggparallel(list("gear", "cyl"), data=mtcars, method='parset')   ## flip plot and rotate text ggparallel(list("gear", "cyl"), data=mtcars, text.angle=0) +   coord_flip()   ## change colour scheme ggparallel(list("gear", "cyl"), data=mtcars, text.angle=0) +   coord_flip() +   scale_fill_brewer(palette="Set1") +   scale_colour_brewer(palette="Set1")   ## example with more than two variables: titanic <- as.data.frame(Titanic) ggparallel(names(titanic)[c(1,4,2,1)], order=0, titanic, weight="Freq") +   scale_fill_brewer(palette="Paired", guide="none") +   scale_colour_brewer(palette="Paired", guide="none") #> Warning: attributes are not identical across measure variables; they will be dropped   if (FALSE) { cols <- c(brewer.pal(5,"Blues")[-1], brewer.pal(3, "Oranges")[-1],           brewer.pal(3, "Greens")[-1]) ggparallel(names(titanic)[c(1,4,2,1)], order=0, titanic, weight="Freq") +   scale_fill_manual(values=cols, guide="none") +   scale_colour_manual(values=cols, guide="none") + theme_bw()  ## hammock plot with same width lines ggparallel(names(titanic)[c(1,4,2,3)], titanic, weight=1, asp=0.5,            method="hammock", ratio=0.2, order=c(0,0)) + theme( legend.position="none") + scale_fill_brewer(palette="Paired") + scale_colour_brewer(palette="Paired")  ## hammock plot with line widths adjusted by frequency ggparallel(names(titanic)[c(1,4,2,3)], titanic, weight="Freq",            asp=0.5, method="hammock", order=c(0,0), text.angle=0,            width=0.45) +   theme( legend.position="none")   ## biological examples: genes and pathways data(genes) cols <- c(rep("grey80", 24), brewer.pal("YlOrRd", n = 9)) genes$chrom <- factor(genes$chrom, levels=c(paste("chr", 1:22, sep=""), "chrX", "chrY")) ggparallel(list("path", "chrom"), text.offset=c(0.03, 0,-0.03),            data = genes,  width=0.1, order=c(1,0), text.angle=0,            color="white",    factorlevels =  c(sapply(unique(genes$chrom), as.character),      unique(genes$path))) +    scale_fill_manual(values = cols, guide="none") +    scale_colour_manual(values = cols, guide="none") +    coord_flip() }  data(Titanic) titanic <- as.data.frame(Titanic)  titanic$SexSurvived <- with(titanic, interaction(Sex, Survived)) titanic$SexClassSurvived <- with(titanic, interaction(Sex,Class, Survived))  ggparallel(vars=list("Survived", "SexSurvived", "SexClassSurvived"), weight="Freq", data=titanic) +   theme(legend.position="none") +   scale_fill_manual(values = rep(c("Orange", "Steelblue"), 14)) +   scale_colour_manual(values = rep(c("Orange", "Steelblue"), 14))   ###########  p1 <- ggparallel(vars=list("Survived", "SexSurvived", "SexClassSurvived"),                  weight="Freq", data=titanic, label = FALSE) +   theme(legend.position="none") +   scale_fill_manual(values = rep(c("Orange", "Steelblue"), 14)) +   scale_colour_manual(values = rep(c("Orange", "Steelblue"), 14)) p2 <- ggparallel(vars=list("Survived", "SexSurvived", "SexClassSurvived"),                  weight="Freq", data=titanic, label = TRUE) +   theme(legend.position="none") +   scale_fill_manual(values = rep(c("Orange", "Steelblue"), 14)) +   scale_colour_manual(values = rep(c("Orange", "Steelblue"), 14))  ggplot_build(p2)$data[[4]] #>       x       y           label PANEL group colour size angle hjust vjust alpha #> 1  1.01  355.49             Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 2  1.01 1455.99              No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 3  2.01   62.99       Female.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 4  2.01  297.99      Female.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 5  2.01  653.49        Male.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 6  2.01 1518.99         Male.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 7  3.01    1.49  Female.Crew.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 8  3.01    4.99   Female.1st.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 9  3.01   13.49   Female.2nd.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 10 3.01   29.99 Female.Crew.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 11 3.01   52.49    Male.2nd.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 12 3.01   95.99    Male.1st.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 13 3.01  170.99    Male.3rd.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 14 3.01  259.99  Female.3rd.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 15 3.01  351.49  Female.2nd.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 16 3.01  450.99   Female.3rd.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 17 3.01  562.99     Male.1st.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 18 3.01  692.49  Female.1st.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 19 3.01  839.99     Male.2nd.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 20 3.01 1012.99   Male.Crew.Yes     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 21 3.01 1319.99     Male.3rd.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #> 22 3.01 1865.99    Male.Crew.No     1    -1 grey90    4    90   0.5   0.5    NA #>    family fontface lineheight #> 1                1        1.2 #> 2                1        1.2 #> 3                1        1.2 #> 4                1        1.2 #> 5                1        1.2 #> 6                1        1.2 #> 7                1        1.2 #> 8                1        1.2 #> 9                1        1.2 #> 10               1        1.2 #> 11               1        1.2 #> 12               1        1.2 #> 13               1        1.2 #> 14               1        1.2 #> 15               1        1.2 #> 16               1        1.2 #> 17               1        1.2 #> 18               1        1.2 #> 19               1        1.2 #> 20               1        1.2 #> 21               1        1.2 #> 22               1        1.2 p1 + geom_text(aes(x = x, y=y, label = label), data = ggplot_build(p2)$data[[4]])

what: A package for creating parallel coordinates for categorical data — package-ggparallel
title: A package for creating parallel coordinates for categorical data — package-ggparallel
text: main function ggparallel implements three types parallel coordinate plots categorical data: hammock plots, parallel sets plots, common angle plots.
